#summary Creating MetaBoxes for your Custom Content Type
#labels Custom-Fields
#sidebar Sidebar



Starting with version 0.9.7, you can customize your manager forms by creating metaboxes.

This relies on !WordPress' [http://codex.wordpress.org/Function_Reference/add_meta_box add_meta_box()] function.  You can create your own custom meta boxes when you are managing the custom fields for a post-type.

= Metabox Settings ==

 *ID* (_required_): the unique CSS ID for the metabox.
 *Title* (_required_): appears at the top of the box.
 *Context* : controls where on the page the box will be drawn: advanced, normal, side.
 *Priority* : controls order within a context
 *Callback Function*: use this if you want you own custom behavior
 *Callback Arguments*: use this if you have specified your own callback funciton.

See [http://codex.wordpress.org/Function_Reference/add_meta_box add_meta_box()] for more info.

= Custom Formatting =

== Hierarchy =

Any time (almost) when the CCTM generates HTML in the !WordPress manager, the CCTM relies on tokenized formatting template (*.tpl*) files to generate the final output.  Here's a visual example:

https://img.skitch.com/20110927-mip2pscb7snftaa3eu3isgqjhx.png

-----

== Directories ==

You can override the HTML used to draw a metabox by creating the following directory structure inside of your !WordPress *wp-content/uploads* directory:

{{{
cctm/metaboxes/
}}}

The `_default.tpl` template is used by default if no other matching template file is found.  To use a custom format for a given metabox, create a file corresponding to its ID, e.g. if the metabox ID is "mymetabox", then the file you should create is`cctm/metaboxes/mymetabox.tpl`.

|| http://s2.postimage.org/by3ngezo/warning_icon.png || Never add to or overwrite the template files inside of the `plugins/custom-content-type-manager/` directory!  Always add your modifications to `wp-content/uploads/cctm/`so that they are not overwritten during updates to the CCTM. ||
